pull.title: Specify BIP-fidelity-bonds
pull.body:
This adds a BIP for a standard for storing fidelity bonds in BIP39 seed phrases.

Preferably the BIP number will be a two-digit number to match the BIP44, BIP49, BIP84, BIP86 family of BIPs. Alternatively if a three-digit number is the only way then I suggest BIP-842 because it matches the bip32 derivation path `m / 84' / 0' / 0' / 2 / index`

labels.name: PR Author action required
labels.description: Needs updates, has unaddressed review comments, or is otherwise waiting for PR author

issue.title: Implementing BIP for restoring fidelity bonds from seed phrases
issue.body:
Hello

I recently [opened a PR](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1341) to get a BIP number assigned for the standard for storing fidelity bonds in bip39 seed phrases. It can also be read on the gist: https://gist.github.com/chris-belcher/7257763cedcc014de2cd4239857cd36e

The fidelity bonds in joinmarket are held in bip39 seed phrases. It would be pretty nice if people could restore their fidelity bond coins by importing the same bip39 seed into another wallet, like Electrum. Also it would allow for fidelity bonds to be held in cold storage, allowing the sybil resistance of such systems to increase without hot wallet risk.

I was thinking write code and open a PR to add this to Electrum along with the other BIP39 wallet types. I'm wondering if anyone has thoughts around the codebase for the best way to do that. I've read a little bit around the codebase already but not much.

A big difference with the fidelity bonds BIP compared to others like bip44/bip82 is there are not an infinite number of addresses. There are only 960 time-locked addresses, one for each month from 2020-01-01 until 2099-12-01. There are no gap limits, instead the wallet always generates all 960 addresses and sync's them.

To actually spend the coin the same witness is required as any other address type: `<signature> <pubkey>`. However the `nLockTime` of the transaction has to be set to greater than the address timelock.

I'm reading a bit around the Electrum code, for example here: https://github.com/spesmilo/electrum/blob/9e0a0af81a7dab4fe22aeb007fb5560f48dc6433/electrum/bip39_recovery.py I think the best way is to modify the function `bitcoin.pubkey_to_address` to take an optional parameter `index` which inside the script type can be converted to a timelock value [using the formula from the bip](https://gist.github.com/chris-belcher/7257763cedcc014de2cd4239857cd36e#timelock-derivation). Or maybe this can be done in a special if-statement instead of somehow in the `pubkey_to_address` function. Then set the gap limit to be 960. Also somewhere in the GUI should be displayed the timelock as a formatted datetime, perhaps the best way is to set the description field to be automatically set to say `2020-01-01` or whatever the date is.

If you have any thoughts for coding this up do let me know. I hope to write the code eventually. Also if you think this is all a really bad idea let me know so I don't waste time coding it up. Though hopefully I can convince you that fidelity bonds are really great, joinmarket already has hundreds of bitcoins locked up some for years, and this provides excellent protection from sybil attacks. Here's a thread explaining a bit: https://twitter.com/chris_belcher_/status/1432696845017436166 (Although the thread is several months old, the numbers are bigger now)

issue.title: Implementing BIP for restoring fidelity bonds from seed phrases
issue.body:
Hello

I recently [opened a PR](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1341) to get a BIP number assigned for the standard for storing fidelity bonds in bip39 seed phrases. It can also be read on the gist: https://gist.github.com/chris-belcher/7257763cedcc014de2cd4239857cd36e

Fidelity bonds are really great, joinmarket already has hundreds of bitcoins locked up some for years, and this provides excellent protection from sybil attacks. Here's a thread explaining a bit: https://twitter.com/chris_belcher_/status/1432696845017436166 (Although the thread is several months old, the numbers are bigger now)

The fidelity bonds in joinmarket are held in bip39 seed phrases. It would be pretty nice if people could restore their fidelity bond coins by importing the same bip39 seed into another wallet, like Sparrow. Also it would allow for fidelity bonds to be held in cold storage, allowing the sybil resistance of such systems to increase without hot wallet risk.

Would you consider implementing this in Sparrow? Would you accept a PR if someone else implemented it?

Do consider having a look at [the BIP itself](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1341), it's currently in the process of being assigned a BIP number.

events.body: This doesn't actually use BIP39 -- I think it would be clearer and more general to just say "storing fidelity bonds in BIP32 hierarchical trees" and leave the encoding of the master seed out of scope.

events.message:
Specify BIP-fidelity-bonds

For storing fidelity bonds in HD wallets

events.body: Good thinking. I checked the other similar BIPs and I see they don't mention BIP39 either.
Needs a section to address backward compatibility (even if it simply explains why it's not applicable)
@chris-belcher are you still working on this?
